Si bien con la nueva actualizacion la hitbox de los survivors es una caca, cuando la fixeen va seguir siendo el mismo juego de antes, que por cierto (para mi) es alto juegazo para viciar y cagarte de risa con amigos

Don't BUY/PLAY if you intended to play mainly by yourself as a survivor. 
Your first dozen of hour will be miserable. DBD has a long learning curve, you have to remember blueprint of maps: where is the pallet/window/totem/gens and they located differently every game to increase randomness. There is around 30 maps. You also need to know perks, you will spend quite a time to figure out a set of it that suit for you or sometimes you can copy directly from streamer or strangers in your team; anyway at least 20hours are invested to earn the bloodpoints and learn the skills you need. The game starts here. Also lame tutorial, it merely let you know some basic, so you do not stand here like a fool. Knowledge of killers skills and perks are a must as it will influence how to play the game: hide or run, fix the gen or unhook your teammates, etc.. In fact, learning to move your mouse could take hours, try look behind when playing and you will know.

If you okay with all above, appox 100 hours should be played and you reached red rank.
As the game is 5 years old, lots of players spend 10,000 plus hours in this game, you gonna meet them since now. And things will get stressful, at red rank every second counts, your entire team maybe crashed/downed in less than 30secs in lots of situation, killers also have many tricks to hit you, when I played 200 hours I thought 500 hours will make me a solider, at 500 hours I thought 1k hours make me qualified to face but not survive most of the killer. Not the case. Remember the long learning curve things? 1k hours really just the beginning, prepare for 5k. BTW the game does not really take talents, more playtime, more you get. 

Did I mentioned toxicity and bugs? Some of them are structural, even if you report after game and devs longed to fix it, they still exist and directly influence the game experience negatively. Both of them can easily make you a bad mood, better choice within meters if you wanna relax and refreshed.  Also, even the community agreed dbd is addictive in a bad way. It makes players angry/upset and somehow they want more, it is a sad loop for sure. I hope i know it before I downloaded this game. 
Since Im writing about playing alone, fully prepare for your stranger teammates, Half of them knows how to play, the other half? they disconnect, leave you on hook, not coop, sometimes toxic. You should aware this is not a shooter game, you need to fix 5 gens and open the gate. Every survivor counts and need to contribute to the goal, NOT FINISHED

Game was broken and was fixed, it still has issues but overall does not affect its game play. To the "I think we're doing a pretty good job so far" Devs, focus on the bugs and not giving the game a new UI or the characters a make-over of what was already perfect. Still a decent game for anyone wishing to try a completely new genre of games. Dead by daylight is definitely one of a kind.

The latest UI update was pretty much universally hated by everyone on the ptb but they added it anyways because the level of arrogance from the devs is quite unlike anything I've seen from other game development companies. It's almost impossible as the killer to keep track of the status of survivors due to how out of the way that information is and the same can be said if you're playing a killer that needs to manage a resource (Michael Myers, for example). They also added new survivor animations that took away movement options from skilled survivors and in the process completely broke the hitboxes making the game currently borderline unplayable for the survivor side.

This game is normally actually pretty great and surprisingly well balanced, considering it's an Asymmetrical game. However, in its current state, I can't recommend anyone picking it up. Hopefully the devs fix this issue that they've caused quickly.

Edit: So they fixed both the hitbox issues and smoothed out the survivor movement animations, giving them back the movement tech they had previously lost. They also adjusted the UI so it's not as horrible as it was before but it's still not as good as the old one. I'd say the game is again worth buying in its current state but if you do decide to purchase it, be prepared to deal with some of the most arrogant devs you've ever seen. It'll only be a matter of time before they make some horrible change to the game that no one asked for while the entire community is pleading with them not to go through with it.

DBD is always on sale at some point, so wait until then to purchase it.

Fun multiplayer game to solo-queue in or party up with friends (Recommend playing with friends to make experience easier and more fun); Offers a lot of killers and survivors to choose from, as well as many maps and DLCs that fail to disappoint. Matchmaking can be a bit of a hit-or-miss and the game can be buggy sometimes. The community is also toxic and balance decisions made for this game are poor, to say the least. The biggest issue I have with the game currently is the forced crossplay between PC and console players; Games can feel unbalanced due to keyboard/controller advantages/disadvantages and I wish they gave players an option to not have crossplay on. There is definitely room for improvement, and I hope Behaviour will take notice to the complaints and refine their work. Even so, I enjoy playing the game casually and not competitively.

Rating: 7.25/10

The game has a few updates which nearly killed itself. The last update is one of this kind. I have NEVER experienced the game in such an unbalanced state since its release. I respect the developers hard work to reduce their player numbers in record time - which they have successfully done once again. Any kind of fun I ever had in this game has been fully taken from me and my friends since the last update rolled out. If they do plan on leaving the game in the current state, I hope they're working on a new project because this decision had the potential to kill this game ultimately.

Dead by Daylight is not a game for everyone. Progression is uninteresting, comes at a trickle, and has a unique but compounding mechanic; compounding in that it reinforces the previously mentioned problem. The game keeps so tight a leash on the graphical settings that some people may be turned off because of it. This is done under the pretense of maintaining the competitive nature of the game. 

Ultimately, DbD is an unpolished game that intentionally slows player development to encourage the use of the microtransaction store. Instead of polishing their very much unfinished, underdesigned game, the devs have chosen to push out a mixture of fluffy cosmetics or frequently strong DLC characters (again, incentivising you to spend more money).

If you can get past all these issues and enjoy the game, that's great! I hope you get out of it exactly what you want to. For me, however, this game is a hard pass that actively repulses me with the direction the devs have taken it.
